text:
Marble Hill Ave. (formerly Kingsbridge Ave., running from right fore, to center background), north from and including West 227th Street (formerly Wicker Place), showing King's Bridge, thrown across Spuyten Duyvil Creek (no longer in existence) and connecting Manhattan with the Bronx. The 3-story white frame house (right) bears No. 86; next to it, but slightly separated is No. 96, a 2½-story frame house, partially obstructing from view St. Stephen's (M.E.) Church, another frame structure, at the S.E. corner of Marble Hill Ave. and West 228th Street (formerly Terrace View Ave.). The 2½-story frame house, shown prominently, on the left, bears No. 91 Marble Hill Ave., at the N.W. corner of West 227th Street, and is seen facing the latter Street. Between Marble Hill Ave. and the Creek is visible a portion of West 228th Street, and across the Creek, in a northeasterly direction, is the Borough of The Bronx, as seen from the former site of Fort Prince Charles (hill, left foreground). The fort was built in 1776 during the Revolution and was named after Prince Charles William Ferdinand, brother-in-law of King George III. It was constructed for the purpose of controlling passage across King's Bridge, over Spuyten Duyvil Creek, which in turn was built in 1693 by a royal grant given to Frederick Philipse, by King William III, after whom it was named. In 1776 when the Hessian Army made decisive advances against the Colonials the fort was abandoned and in November, the Hessians who took possession of it, named it Fort Prince of Brunswick, a brother-in-law of King George III of England. This area is rich with the glorious traditions of the Colonials, who fought in these environs many a battle under George Washington's command. A flag pole now commemorates the site of the Fort. March 28, 1906.

Brown Brothers.

Marble Hill Ave., (formerly Kingsbridge Ave., running from right center, to center background), north from and including West 227th Street (left, formerly Wicker Place), showing King's Bridge, thrown across Spuyten Duyvil Creek (no longer in existence) and connecting Manhattan with the Bronx. On the right slightly hidden by tree, is No. 96, a 2½ story frame house, obstructing from view (partially) St. Stephen's Church (M.E.), at the S.E. corner of 228th Street. Across the Creek are visible the hills in the Bronx, as seen from the former site of Fort Prince Charles (hill, left foreground, now 1937 occupied by a 6-story apartment house, the Fort Prince Charles Court). For further data see view 1.

March 28, 1906.

Brown Brothers.

West 227th Street, west from Marble Hill Ave., showing W.P.A. employees repairing street bed.

May 8, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

West 227th Street, west from Marble Hill, to Adrian Aves. Shown on the right is No. 91 Marble Hill Ave., at the N.W. corner. The two frame houses on the left are Nos. 118 and 116 West 227th Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Van Corlear Place.

May 8, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

West 227th Street, west from Marble Hill Ave., showing W.P.A. employees repairing the street. On the left appears a portion of the Fort Prince Charles Court, an apartment house at the S.W. corner of Fort Charles Place (converges with Marble Hill Ave., at this point).

May 8, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
